awd_titl_txt: RUI: Computational Methods for Measuring Topological Entanglement in Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to investigate the effects of polymer entanglement and architecture on material properties using computational and mathematical techniques. Entangled polymer physics are a subject of study since Edwards' original model in the 60's which is still under examination. Under some conditions we can see polymer chains as mathematical curves in space and measure their topological complexity. However, the use of topological entanglement for the study of polymer entanglement has not been fully explored, due to the difficulty of bridging the two notions, requiring background from topology and polymer physics and engineering. The project consists of an inter-disciplinary effort with researchers from Mathematics and Chemical Engineering to solve the problem of quantifying the effects of topological entanglement and polymer architecture to material properties of polymers. Our contribution is an innovative approach that integrates analytical, computational and experimental methods to solve a problem at the interface of polymer physics, topology and geometry. Understanding how microscopic properties affect material properties will lead not only to the smart manufacturing of new materials, but also to the understanding of living matter. This award will support 1 graduate student for each of the three years of the project.
 
In order to understand and quantify the interplay between microstructure and macroscopic properties of polymers, we propose to use mathematical concepts from topology and investigate properties of polymers at different length-scales through computer simulations. Our results will be complemented and validated by experimental data.  The proposed works can be summarized as follows: (1) the creation of new methods to account for polymer entanglement in Self-Consistent Field Theory (SCFT) simulations, (2) the development of new partitioned algorithms to simulate the fluid-structure interaction for entangled polymers (3) the development of new computational user-packages for measuring topological entanglement of open curves and (4) the combined application of all the above mentioned tools to understand the self-assembly, organization and viscoelastic properties of polymer melts of varying architecture using simulations and experiments.   This study advances knowledge at the area of topology and geometry, by defining and studying new tools for measuring the geometrical/topological complexity of open curves in space and also advances computational infrastructure, by designing and prototyping algorithms in reusable code that in particular studies aspects in entangled polymer simulations (such as fluid-structure interactions for such systems and topological interactions). This work also extends SCFT simulations to account for topological aspects of polymers in a way that it is computationally feasible, which is presently absent in SCFT simulations. This holistic approach will thoroughly study entanglement in polymers of varying architecture that are currently of great interest in materials and manufacturing and nanotechnology, with the potential of immediate impact of our results to practical manufacturing. Our results also provide valuable tools for studying biopolymers with potential impact in biotechnology. This project has educational objectives including strong impact on undergraduate research with a commitment in promoting underrepresented groups in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to establish a new mathematical and computational framework to investigate the intriguing dynamics of polymer entanglement. The project brings together researchers from mathematics and chemical engineering to understand and quantify the effects of topological entanglement on material properties of polymers, a long-standing open problem. The research efforts represent an inter-disciplinary and inter-institutional collaboration between the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga and Arizona State University. The project also involves collaborators at UC Santa Barbara and Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

With the support from NSF, the project team has conducted research at the interface of topology, geometry, numerical analysis and polymer physics, utilizing both analytical and computational approaches. More precisely, a new framework in topology was introduced that enables the rigorous study of open curves in three-dimensional space which opens a new direction in knot theory and its applications. In addition, computational methods were developed, together with the creation of software that enables the application of the mathematical tools stemming from this new theory in practice. In particular, a computational package for polymers, proteins and periodic structures that computes several invariants and measures of entanglement of open curves in three-dimensional space was developed and became freely available to the scientific community via GitHub. The team also conducted numerical simulation of polymer structures at the molecular and atomic levels by employing various macro-molecular modeling methods that are suitable in different contexts, such as Molecular Dynamics and Self-Consistent Field Theory simulations. By employing the topological and geometrical parameters developed in this project, it was shown that critical time scales and length scales of polymer melts and solutions of various architectures are related to the underlying mathematical entanglement complexity. This novel quantitative approach to polymer structure complexity offers the possibility of engineering material properties by rigorously controlling topological entanglement. Additionally, the team developed a new computational model to study the complex interaction between entangled polymers and solutions in polymeric fluids, which is of particular relevance to active biological systems. The methods developed in this project were general and in the framework of this award it was shown that these novel topological methods enable the quantitative analysis of protein structures. Particularly, it was shown these mathematical metrics correlate with experimentally observed aspects of protein kinetics and have the ability to predict aspects of protein mutation related to protein rearrangement, as it occurs in viral proteins.

The project has provided rich education and training opportunities for students at both the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga and Arizona State University. Over the course of this project, the faculty members have supported and engaged more than twelve undergraduates and more than six graduate students, including eight students from underrepresented groups, for research training at the interface of mathematics, computation, and polymer physics. Their research efforts have generated numerous publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals. Moreover, six of the manuscripts were co-authored with undergraduate students. Project findings have also been disseminated through presentation at professional conferences, organization of workshops and seminars, and outreach to the community at large by both the PIs and their students.
